Text

[Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes took [his]108-holmes bottle from the corner of the mantelpiece , and [his]108-holmes hypodermic syringe from its neat morocco case . With [his]108-holmes long , white , nervous fingers [he]108-holmes adjusted the delicate needle , and rolled back [his]108-holmes left shirt - cuff . For some little time [his]108-holmes eyes rested thoughtfully upon the sinewy forearm and wrist , all dotted and scarred with innumerable puncture - marks . Finally , [he]108-holmes thrust the sharp point home , pressed down the tiny piston , and sank back into the velvet - lined arm - chair with a long sigh of satisfaction . Three times a day for many months [I]0-i had witnessed this performance , but custom had not reconciled [my]0-i mind to it . On the contrary , from day to day [I]0-i had become more irritable at the sight , and [my]0-i conscience swelled nightly within [me]0-i at the thought that [I]0-i had lacked the courage to protest . Again and again [I]0-i had registered a vow that [I]0-i should deliver [my]0-i soul upon the subject ; but there was that in the cool , nonchalant air of [[my]0-i companion]202-my companion which made [him]108-holmes [the last man with whom one would care to take anything approaching to a liberty]203-the last man with whom one would care to take anything approaching to a liberty . [His]108-holmes great powers , [his]108-holmes masterly manner , and the experience which [I]0-i had had of [his]108-holmes many extraordinary qualities , all made [me]0-i diffident and backward in crossing [him]108-holmes . Yet upon that afternoon , whether it was the Beaune which [I]0-i had taken with [my]0-i lunch , or the additional exasperation produced by the extreme deliberation of [his]108-holmes manner , [I]0-i suddenly felt that [I]0-i could hold out no longer . ' Which is it to - day , '[0-i] [I]0-i asked , ' morphine or cocaine ? '[0-i] [He]108-holmes raised [his]108-holmes eyes languidly from the old black - letter volume which [he]108-holmes had opened . ' It is cocaine , '[108-holmes] [he]108-holmes said , ' a seven - per - cent . solution . Would [you]0-i care to try it ? '[108-holmes] ' No , indeed , '[0-i] [I]0-i answered brusquely . ' [My]0-i constitution has not got over the Afghan campaign yet . [I]0-i can not afford to throw any extra strain upon it . '[0-i] [He]108-holmes smiled at [my]0-i vehemence . ' Perhaps [you]0-i are right , [Watson]109-watson , '[108-holmes] [he]108-holmes said . ' [I]108-holmes suppose that its influence is physically a bad one . [I]108-holmes find it , however , so transcendently stimulating and clarifying to the mind that its secondary action is a matter of small moment . '[108-holmes] ' But consider ! '[0-i] [I]0-i said earnestly . ' Count the cost ! [Your]0-i brain may , as [you]0-i say , be roused and excited , but it is a pathological and morbid process , which involves increased tissue - change and may at last leave a permanent weakness . [You]0-i know , too , what a black reaction comes upon [you]0-i . Surely the game is hardly worth the candle . Why should [you]0-i , for a mere passing pleasure , risk the loss of those great powers with which [you]0-i have been endowed ? Remember that [I]0-i speak not only as [one comrade]1281-one comrade to [another]1282-another , but as [a medical man to one for whose constitution [he]0-i is to some extent answerable]1283-a medical man to one for whose constitution he is to some extent answerable . " [He]108-holmes did not seem offended . On the contrary , [he]108-holmes put [his]108-holmes finger - tips together , and leaned [his]108-holmes elbows on the arms of [his]108-holmes chair , like [one who has a relish for conversation]1284-one who has a relish for conversation . '[0-i] [My]0-i mind , ' [he]108-holmes said , '[0-i] rebels at stagnation . Give [me]0-i problems , give [me]0-i work , give [me]0-i the most abstruse cryptogram , or the most intricate analysis , and [I]0-i am in [my]0-i own proper atmosphere . [I]0-i can dispense then with artificial stimulants . But [I]0-i abhor the dull routine of existence . [I]0-i crave for mental exaltation . That is why [I]0-i have chosen [my]0-i own particular profession , or rather created it , for [I]0-i am [the only one in [the world]205-the world]204-the only one in the world . ' '[206-the only unofficial detective] [The only unofficial detective]206-the only unofficial detective ? ' [I]207-the only unofficial consulting detective said , raising [my]207-the only unofficial consulting detective eyebrows . '[207-the only unofficial consulting detective] [The only unofficial consulting detective]207-the only unofficial consulting detective , ' [he]0-i answered . '[207-the only unofficial consulting detective] [I]0-i am [the last and highest court of appeal in detection]208-the last and highest court of appeal in detection . When , [Gregson]110-gregson , or [Lestrade]111-lestrade , or [Athelney Jones]112-jones are out of [their]209-their depths — which , by the way , is [their]209-their normal state — the matter is laid before [me]0-i . [I]0-i examine the data , as [an expert]210-an expert , and pronounce [a specialist]211-a specialist 's opinion . [I]0-i claim no credit in such cases . [My]0-i name figures in no newspaper . The work itself , the pleasure of finding a field for [my]0-i peculiar powers , is [my]0-i highest reward . But [you]212-you have [yourself]212-you had some experience of [my]0-i methods of work in the Jefferson Hope case . ' '[212-you] Yes , indeed , ' said [I]212-you cordially . '[212-you] [I]0-i was never so struck by anything in [my]0-i life . [I]0-i even embodied it in a small brochure , with the somewhat fantastic title of " A Study in [Scarlet]1-scarlet . " ' [He]0-i shook [his]0-i head sadly . '[0-i] [I]0-i glanced over it , ' said [he]0-i . '[0-i] Honestly , [I]0-i can not congratulate [you]212-you upon it . Detection is , or ought to be , an exact science , and should be treated in the same cold and unemotional manner . [You]212-you have attempted to tinge it with romanticism , which produces much the same effect as if [you]212-you worked a lovestory or an elopement into the fifth proposition of [Euclid]113-euclid . ' '[212-you] But the romance was there , ' [I]0-i remonstrated . '[0-i] [I]0-i could not tamper with the facts . ' '[0-i] Some facts should be suppressed , or , at least , a just sense of proportion should be observed in treating them . The only point in the case which deserved mention was the curious analytical reasoning from effects to causes , by which [I]0-i succeeded in unravelling it . ' [I]0-i was annoyed at this criticism of a work which had been specially designed to please [him]0-i . [I]0-i confess , too , that [I]0-i was irritated by the egotism which seemed to demand that every line of [my]0-i pamphlet should be devoted to [his]0-i own special doings . More than once during the years that [I]0-i had lived with [him]0-i in [Baker Street]1285-baker street [I]0-i had observed that a small vanity underlay [[my]0-i companion]202-my companion 's quiet and didactic manner . [I]0-i made no remark , however , but sat nursing [my]0-i wounded leg . [I]0-i had had a Jezail bullet through it some time before , and , though it did not prevent [me]0-i from walking , it ached wearily at every change of the weather . '[0-i] [My]0-i practice has extended recently to [the Continent]2-the continent , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes , after awhile , filling up [his]0-i old briar - root pipe . '[0-i] [I]0-i was consulted last week by [François le Villard]114-françois le villard , who , as [you]213-you probably know , has come rather to the front lately in [the French detective service]214-the french detective service . [He]114-françois le villard has all the Celtic power of quick intuition , but [he]114-françois le villard is deficient in the wide range of exact knowledge which is essential to the higher developments of [his]114-françois le villard art . The case was concerned with a will , and possessed some features of interest . [I]0-i was able to refer [him]114-françois le villard to two parallel cases , the one at [Riga]3-riga in 1857 , and the other at [St. Louis]4-st. louis in 1871 , which have suggested to [him]114-françois le villard the true solution . Here is the letter which [I]0-i had this morning acknowledging [my]0-i assistance . ' [He]114-françois le villard tossed over , as [he]114-françois le villard spoke , a crumpled sheet of foreign notepaper . [I]114-françois le villard glanced [my]114-françois le villard eyes down it , catching a profusion of notes of admiration , with stray '[114-françois le villard] magnifiques , ' '[114-françois le villard] coup - de - maîtres , ' and '[114-françois le villard] tours - de - force , ' all testifying to the ardent admiration of [the Frenchman]1287-the frenchman . '[114-françois le villard] [He]114-françois le villard speaks as a pupil to [[his]114-françois le villard master]215-his master , ' said [I.]114-françois le villard '[114-françois le villard] Oh , [he]114-françois le villard rates [my]0-i assistance too highly , ' said [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes lightly . '[114-françois le villard] [He]114-françois le villard has considerable gifts [himself]114-françois le villard . [He]114-françois le villard possesses two out of the three qualities necessary for [the ideal detective]216-the ideal detective . [He]114-françois le villard has the power of observation and that of deduction . [He]114-françois le villard is only wanting in knowledge , and that may come in time . [He]114-françois le villard is now translating [my]0-i small works into French . ' '[114-françois le villard] [Your]0-i works ? ' '[114-françois le villard] Oh , did n't [you]0-i know ? ' [he]114-françois le villard cried , laughing . '[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i have been guilty of several monographs . They are all upon technical subjects . Here , for example , is one " Upon the Distinction between the Ashes of the Various Tobaccos . " In it [I]0-i enumerate a hundred and forty forms of cigar , cigarette , and pipe tobacco , with coloured plates illustrating the difference in the ash . It is a point which is continually turning up in criminal trials , and which is sometimes of supreme importance as a clue . If [you]217-you can say definitely , for example , that some murder had been done by [a man who was smoking [an Indian lunkah]219-an indian lunkah]218-a man who was smoking an indian lunkah , it obviously narrows [your]217-you field of search . To the trained eye there is as much difference between the black ash of a Trichinopoly and the white fluff of bird's - eye as there is between a cabbage and a potato . ' '[0-i] [You]0-i have an extraordinary genius for minutiæ , ' [I]0-i remarked . '[0-i] [I]0-i appreciate their importance . Here is [my]0-i monograph upon the tracing of footsteps , with some remarks upon the uses of plaster of [Paris]5-paris as a preserver of impresses . Here , too , is a curious little work upon the influènce of a trade upon the form of the hand , with lithotypes of the hands of [slaters]220-slaters , [sailors]221-sailors , [cork - cutters]222-cork - cutters , [compositors]223-compositors , [weavers]224-weavers , and [diamond - polishers]225-diamond - polishers . That is a matter of great practical interest to [the scientific detective]226-the scientific detective — especially in cases of unclaimed bodies , or in discovering the antecedents of [criminals]227-criminals . But [I]0-i weary [you]217-you with [my]0-i hobby . ' '[0-i] Not at all , ' [I]0-i answered earnestly . '[0-i] It is of the greatest interest to [me]0-i , especially since [I]0-i have had the opportunity of observing [your]217-you practical application of it . But [you]217-you spoke just now of observation and deduction . Surely the one to some extent implies the other . ' '[217-you] Why , hardly , ' [he]217-you answered , leaning back luxuriously in [his]217-you armchair , and sending up thick blue wreaths from [his]217-you pipe . '[217-you] For example , observation shows [me]0-i that [you]217-you have been to [the Wigmore Street Post - Office]228-the wigmore street post - office this morning , but deduction lets [me]0-i know that when there [you]217-you despatched a telegram . ' '[217-you] Right ! ' said [I.]0-i '[217-you] Right on both points ! But [I]0-i confess that [I]0-i do n't see how [you]217-you arrived at it . It was a sudden impulse upon [my]0-i part , and [I]0-i have mentioned it to [no one]229-no one . ' '[0-i] It is simplicity itself , ' [he]217-you remarked , chuckling at [my]0-i surprise—'so absurdly simple that an explanation is superfluous ; and yet it may serve to define the limits of observation and of deduction . Observation tells [me]0-i that [you]217-you have a little reddish mould adhering to [your]217-you instep . Just opposite [the Wigmore Street Office]1288-the wigmore street office [they]1289-they have taken up [the pavement]1290-the pavement and thrown up some earth , which lies in such a way that it is difficult to avoid treading in it in entering . The earth is of this peculiar reddish tint which is found , as far as [I]0-i know , nowhere else in [the neighbourhood]1291-the neighbourhood . So much is observation . The rest is deduction . '[0-i] ' How , then , did [you]0-i deduce the telegram ? '[0-i] ' Why , of course [I]0-i knew that [you]217-you had not written a letter , since [I]0-i sat opposite to [you]217-you all morning . [I]0-i see also in [your]217-you open desk there that [you]217-you have a sheet of stamps and a thick bundle of postcards . What could [you]217-you go into [the post - office]1292-the post - office for , then , but to send a wire ? Eliminate all other factors , and the one which remains must be the truth . '[0-i] ' In this case it certainly is so , '[0-i] [I]0-i replied , after a little thought . ' The thing , however , is , as [you]230-you say , of the simplest . Would [you]230-you think [me]0-i impertinent if [I]0-i were to put [your]230-you theories to a more severe test ? '[0-i] ' On the contrary , '[230-you] [he]230-you answered ; ' it would prevent [me]230-you from taking a second dose of cocaine . [I]230-you should be delighted to look into any problem which [you]230-you might submit to [me]230-you . '[230-you] ' [I]0-i have heard [you]230-you say that it is difficult for [a man]1293-a man to have any object in daily use without leaving the impress of [his]1293-a man individuality upon it in such a way that [a trained observer]1294-a trained observer might read it . Now , [I]0-i have here a watch which has recently come into [my]0-i possession . Would [you]230-you have the kindness to let [me]0-i have an opinion upon the character or habits of [the late owner]1295-the late owner ? '[0-i] [I]0-i handed [him]230-you over the watch with some slight feeling of amusement in [my]0-i heart , for the test was , as [I]0-i thought , an impossible one , and [I]0-i intended it as a lesson against the somewhat dogmatic tone which [he]230-you occasionally assumed . [He]230-you balanced the watch in [his]230-you hand , gazed hard at the dial , opened the back , and examined the works , first with [his]230-you naked eyes and then with a powerful convex lens . [I]0-i could hardly keep from smiling at [his]230-you crestfallen face when [he]230-you finally snapped the case to and handed it back . ' There are hardly any data , '[230-you] [he]230-you remarked . ' The watch has been recently cleaned , which robs [me]230-you of [my]230-you most suggestive facts . '[230-you] ' [You]230-you are right , '[0-i] [I]0-i answered . ' It was cleaned before being sent to [me]0-i . '[0-i] In [my]0-i heart [I]0-i accused [[my]0-i companion]202-my companion of putting forward a most lame and impotent excuse to cover [his]230-you failure . What data could [he]230-you expect from an uncleaned watch ? ' Though unsatisfactory , [my]230-you research has not been entirely barren , '[230-you] [he]230-you observed , staring up at the ceiling with dreamy , lacklustre eyes . ' Subject to [your]230-you correction , [I]230-you should judge that the watch belonged to [[your]230-you elder brother]1296-your elder brother , who inherited it from [[your]230-you father]1297-your father . '[230-you] ' That [you]230-you gather , no doubt , from the H. W. upon the back ? '[0-i] ' Quite so . The W. suggests [your]230-you own name . The date of the watch is nearly fifty years back , and the initials are as old as the watch : so it was made for the last generation . [Jewellery]115-jewellery usually descends to [the eldest son]1298-the eldest son , and [he]1298-the eldest son is most likely to have the same name as [the father]1299-the father . [[Your]230-you father]1297-your father has , if [I]230-you remember right , been dead many years . It has , therefore , been in the hands of [[your]230-you eldest brother]1301-your eldest brother . '[230-you] ' Right , so far , '[232-i.] said [I.]232-i. ' Anything else ? '[232-i.] ' [He]1301-your eldest brother was [a man of untidy habits]1302-a man of untidy habits — very untidy and careless . [He]1301-your eldest brother was left with good prospects , but [he]1301-your eldest brother threw away [his]1301-your eldest brother chances , lived for some time in poverty with occasional short intervals of prosperity , and finally , taking to drink , [he]1301-your eldest brother died . That is all [I]0-i can gather . '[0-i] [I]0-i sprang from [my]0-i chair and limped impatiently about [the room]233-the room with considerable bitterness in [my]0-i heart . ' This is unworthy of [you]230-you , [Holmes]108-holmes , '[0-i] [I]0-i said . ' [I]0-i could not have believed that [you]230-you would have descended to this . [You]230-you have made inquiries into the history of [[my]0-i unhappy brother]1303-my unhappy brother , and [you]230-you now pretend to deduce this knowledge in some fanciful way . [You]230-you can not expect [me]0-i to believe that [you]230-you have read all this from [his]1303-my unhappy brother old watch ! It is unkind , and , to speak plainly , has a touch of charlatanism in it . '[0-i] ' [[My]234-i dear doctor]1304-my dear doctor , '[234-i] said [he]234-i kindly , ' pray accept [my]234-i apologies . Viewing the matter as an abstract problem , [I]234-i had forgotten how personal and painful a thing it might be to [you]1304-my dear doctor . [I]234-i assure [you]1304-my dear doctor , however , that [I]234-i never even knew that [you]1304-my dear doctor had [a brother]1305-a brother until [you]230-you handed [me]234-i the watch . '[234-i] ' Then how in the name of all that is wonderful did [you]230-you get these facts ? They are absolutely correct in every particular . '[0-i] ' Ah , that is good luck . [I]0-i could only say what was the balance of probability . [I]0-i did not at all expect to be so accurate . '[0-i] ' But it was not mere guess - work ? '[0-i] ' No , no : [I]0-i never guess . It is a shocking habit — destructive to the logical faculty . What seems strange to [you]230-you is only so because [you]230-you do not follow [my]0-i train of thought or observe the small facts upon which large inferences may depend . For example , [I]0-i began by stating that [[your]230-you brother]1306-your brother was careless . When [you]230-you observe the lower part of that watch - case [you]230-you notice that it is not only dinted in two places , but it is cut and marked all over from the habit of keeping other hard objects , such as coins or keys , in the same pocket . Surely it is no great feat to assume that [a man who treats a fifty - guinea watch so cavalierly]1307-a man who treats a fifty - guinea watch so cavalierly must be [a careless man]1308-a careless man . Neither is it a very farfetched inference that [a man who inherits one article of such value]1309-a man who inherits one article of such value is pretty well provided for in other respects . '[0-i] [I]0-i nodded , to show that [I]0-i followed [his]235-his reasoning . ' It is very customary for [pawnbrokers]1310-pawnbrokers in [England]6-england , when [they]1310-pawnbrokers take a watch , to scratch the number of the ticket with a pin - point upon the inside of the case . It is more handy than a label , as there is no risk of the number being lost or transposed . There are no less than four such numbers visible to [my]0-i lens on the inside of this case . Inference — that [[your]230-you brother]1306-your brother was often at low water . Secondary inference — that [he]1306-your brother had occasional bursts of prosperity , or [he]1306-your brother could not have redeemed the pledge . Finally , [I]0-i ask [you]230-you to look at the inner plate , which contains the keyhole . Look at the thousands of scratches all round the hole — marks where the key has slipped . What [sober man]1312-sober man 's key could have scored those grooves ? But [you]230-you will never see [a drunkard]1313-a drunkard 's watch without them . It was a September evening , and not yet seven o'clock , but the day had been a dreary one , and a dense drizzly fog lay low upon [the great city]1352-the great city . Mud - coloured clouds drooped sadly over [the muddy streets]1353-the muddy streets . Down [the Strand]1354-the strand the lamps were but misty splotches of diffused light which threw a feeble circular glimmer upon [the slimy pavement]1355-the slimy pavement . The yellow glare from [the shop]1356-the shop - windows streamed out into the steamy , vaporous air , and threw a murky , shifting radiance across [the crowded thoroughfare]1357-the crowded thoroughfare . There was , to [my]0-i mind , something eerie and ghost - like in the endless procession of faces which flitted across these narrow bars of light — sad faces and glad , haggard and merry . Like [all human kind]1358-all human kind , [they]1358-all human kind flitted from the gloom into the light , and so back into the gloom once more . [I]0-i am not subject to impressions , but the dull , heavy evening , with the strange business upon which [we]327-our were engaged , combined to make [me]0-i nervous and depressed . [I]0-i could see from [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan 's manner that [she]116-miss morstan was suffering from the same feeling . [Holmes]108-holmes alone could rise superior to petty influences . In [that sorry house]1400-that sorry house [it]1400-that sorry house looked as out of place as a diamond of the first water in a setting of brass . The richest and glossiest of curtains and tapestries draped the walls , looped back here and there to expose some richly - mounted painting or Oriental vase . The carpet was of amber and black , so soft and so thick that the foot sank pleasantly into it , as into a bed of moss . Two great tiger - skins thrown athwart it increased the suggestion of Eastern luxury , as did a huge hookah which stood upon a mat in the corner . A lamp in the fashion of a silver dove was hung from an almost invisible golden wire in the centre of [the room]233-the room . As it burned it filled the air with a subtle and aromatic odour . ' Early in 1882 [[my]389-he father]1326-my father received a letter from [India]28-india which was a great shock to [him]1326-my father . What was in the letter [we]375-we could never discover , but [I]389-he could see as [he]1326-my father held it that it was short and written in a scrawling hand . [He]1326-my father had suffered for years from an enlarged spleen , but [he]1326-my father now became rapidly worse , and towards the end of April [we]375-we were informed that [he]1326-my father was beyond all hope , and that [he]1326-my father wished to make a last communication to [us]375-we . '[389-he] When [we]375-we entered [[his]389-he room]390-his room [he]389-he was propped up with pillows and breathing heavily . It is [my]0-i treatment of [poor [Morstan]136-morstan 's orphan]1414-poor morstan 's orphan . The cursed greed which has been [my]0-i besetting sin through life has withheld from [her]1414-poor morstan 's orphan the treasure , half at least of which should have been [hers]1414-poor morstan 's orphan . And yet [I]0-i have made no use of it [myself]0-i , so blind and foolish a thing is avarice . '[0-i] " [I]0-i will tell [you]392-you how [Morstan]136-morstan died , " [he]0-i continued . " [He]136-morstan had suffered for years from a weak heart , but [he]136-morstan concealed it from every one . [I]0-i alone knew it . [I]0-i brought [it]393-it over to [England]6-england , and on the night of [Morstan]136-morstan 's arrival [he]136-morstan came straight over here to claim [his]136-morstan share . [He]136-morstan walked over from [the station]394-the station , and was admitted by [[my]0-i faithful old [Lal Chowdar]138-lal chowdar , who is now dead]138-lal chowdar . [Morstan]136-morstan and [I]0-i had a difference of opinion as to the division of the treasure , and [we]395-we came to heated words . [Morstan]136-morstan had sprung out of [his]136-morstan chair in a paroxysm of anger , when [he]136-morstan suddenly pressed [his]136-morstan hand to [his]136-morstan side , [his]136-morstan face turned a dusky hue , and [he]136-morstan fell backwards , cutting [his]136-morstan head against the corner of the treasure - chest . When [I]0-i stooped over [him]136-morstan [I]0-i found , to [my]0-i horror , that [he]136-morstan was dead . ' " For a long time [I]0-i sat half distracted , wondering what [I]0-i should do . [My]0-i first impulse was , of course , to call for assistance ; but [I]0-i could not but recognise that there was every chance that [I]0-i would be accused of [his]136-morstan murder . [His]136-morstan death at the moment of a quarrel , and the gash in [his]136-morstan head , would be black against [me]0-i . Again , an official inquiry could not be made without bringing out some facts about the treasure , which [I]0-i was particularly anxious to keep secret . [He]136-morstan had told [me]0-i that [no soul upon earth]1417-no soul upon earth knew where [he]136-morstan had gone . There seemed to be no necessity why [any soul]1418-any soul ever should know . '[0-i] " [I]0-i was still pondering over the matter , when , looking up , [I]0-i saw [[my]0-i servant]396-my servant , [Lal Chowdar]138-lal chowdar , in the doorway . [He]138-lal chowdar stole in and bolted the door behind [him]138-lal chowdar . ' Do not fear , [Sahib]139-sahib , '[138-lal chowdar] [he]138-lal chowdar said ; ' [no one]229-no one need know that [you]139-sahib have killed [him]136-morstan . Let [us]1420-us hide [him]136-morstan away , and who is the wiser ? '[138-lal chowdar] ' [I]0-i did not kill [him]136-morstan , '[0-i] said [I.]0-i [Lal Chowdar]138-lal chowdar shook [his]138-lal chowdar head and smiled . ' [I]138-lal chowdar heard it all , [Sahib]139-sahib , '[138-lal chowdar] said [he]138-lal chowdar ; ' [I]138-lal chowdar heard [you]139-sahib quarrel , and [I]138-lal chowdar heard the blow . But [my]138-lal chowdar lips are sealed . [All]1421-all are asleep in [the house]1422-the house . Let [us]1423-us put [him]119-captain morstan away together . '[138-lal chowdar] That was enough to decide [me]0-i . If [[my]0-i own servant]397-my own servant could not believe [my]0-i innocence , how could [I]0-i hope to make it good before [twelve foolish tradesmen]398-twelve foolish tradesmen in a jury - box ? [Lal Chowdar]138-lal chowdar and [I]0-i disposed of the body that night , and within a few days the [London]8-london papers were full of the mysterious disappearance of [Captain Morstan]119-captain morstan . [You]399-you will see from what [I]0-i say that [I]0-i can hardly be blamed in the matter . [My]0-i fault lies in the fact that [we]400-we concealed not only the body , but also the treasure , and that [I]0-i have clung to [Morstan]119-captain morstan 's share as well as to [my]0-i own . [I]0-i wish [you]399-you , therefore , to make restitution . Put [your]399-you ears down to [my]0-i mouth . The treasure is hidden in — " ' At this instant a horrible change came over [his]138-lal chowdar expression ; [his]138-lal chowdar eyes stared wildly , [his]138-lal chowdar jaw dropped , and [he]138-lal chowdar yelled , in a voice which [I]401-we can never forget , " Keep [him]138-lal chowdar out ! For Christ 's sake keep [him]138-lal chowdar out ! " [We]400-we both stared round at the window behind [us]400-we upon which [his]138-lal chowdar gaze was fixed . A face was looking in at [us]400-we out of the darkness . [We]400-we could see the whitening of the nose where it was pressed against the glass . It was [a bearded , hairy face , with wild cruel eyes and an expression of concentrated malevolence]1424-a bearded , hairy face , with wild cruel eyes and an expression of concentrated malevolence . [[My]401-we brother]387-my brother and [I]401-we rushed towards the window , but [the man]1403-the man was gone . When [we]401-we returned to [[my]401-we father]1326-my father [his]1326-my father head had dropped and [his]1326-my father pulse had ceased to beat . '[401-we] [We]401-we searched [the garden]402-the garden that night , but found no sign of [the intruder]403-the intruder , save that just under the window a single footmark was visible in the flower - bed . But for that one trace , [we]401-we might have thought that [our]401-we imaginations had conjured up that wild , fierce face . [We]401-we soon , however , had another and a more striking proof that there were secret agencies at work all round [us]401-we . The window of [[[my]0-i father]1326-my father 's room]405-my father 's room was found open in the morning , [his]1326-my father cupboards and boxes had been rifled , and upon [his]1326-my father chest was fixed a torn piece of paper , with the words " The sign of the four " scrawled across it . What the phrase meant , or who [[our]401-we secret visitor]406-our secret visitor may have been , [we]401-we never knew . As far as [we]401-we can judge , none of [[[my]0-i father]1326-my father 's property]408-my father 's property had been actually stolen , though everything had been turned out . [[My]0-i brother]387-my brother and [I]0-i naturally associated this peculiar incident with the fear which haunted [[my]0-i father]1326-my father during [his]1326-my father life ; but it is still a complete mystery to [us]401-we . ' [The little man]1402-the little man stopped to relight [his]1402-the little man hookah and puffed thoughtfully for a few moments . [We]401-we had all sat absorbed , listening to [his]1326-my father extraordinary narrative . At the short account of [[her]1402-the little man father]1345-her father 's death [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan had turned deadly white , and for a moment [I]387-my brother feared that [she]1402-the little man was about to faint . [She]1402-the little man rallied , however , on drinking a glass of water which [I]387-my brother quietly poured [our]1430-our for [her]1402-the little man from a Venetian carafe upon the side - table . [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes leaned back in [his]108-holmes chair with an abstracted expression and the lids drawn low over [his]108-holmes glittering eyes . As [I]387-my brother glanced at [him]108-holmes [I]387-my brother could not but think how on that very day [he]108-holmes had complained bitterly of the commonplaceness of life . Here at least was a problem which would tax [his]108-holmes sagacity to the utmost . [Mr. Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto looked from one to [the other of [us]414-we]1338-the other of us with an obvious pride at the effect which [his]0-i story had produced , and then continued between the puffs of [his]0-i overgrown pipe . '[387-my brother] [[My]0-i brother]387-my brother and [I]0-i , ' said [he]0-i , '[0-i] were , as [you]412-you may imagine , much excited as to the treasure which [[my]0-i father]1326-my father had spoken of . For weeks and for months [we]414-we dug and delved in every part of [the garden]402-the garden without discovering its whereabouts . It was maddening to think that the hiding - place was on [his]1326-my father very lips at the moment that [he]1326-my father died . [We]414-we could judge the splendour of the missing riches by the chaplet which [he]1326-my father had taken out . Over this chaplet [[my]0-i brother]387-my brother [Bartholomew]130-brother bartholomew and [I]0-i had some little discussion . The pearls were evidently of great value , and [he]1326-my father was averse to part with them , for , between [friends]417-friends , [[my]0-i brother]387-my brother was [himself]387-my brother a little inclined to [[my]0-i father]1326-my father 's fault . [He]1326-my father thought , too , that if [we]414-we parted with [the chaplet]420-the chaplet it might give rise to gossip , and finally bring [us]414-we into trouble . ' '[1326-my father] It was a kindly thought , ' said [[our]414-we companion]1351-our companion earnestly ; '[1326-my father] it was extremely good of [you]0-i . [We]414-we had plenty of money [ourselves]414-we . [I]0-i desired no more . Besides , it would have been such bad taste to have treated [a young lady]422-a young lady in so scurvy a fashion . " Le mauvais goût mène au crime . " [The French]140-the french have a very neat way of putting these things . Yesterday , however , [I]0-i learn that an event of extreme importance has occurred . The treasure has been discovered . [I]0-i instantly communicated with [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan , and it only remains for [us]414-we to drive out to [Norwood]26-norwood and demand [our]414-we share . ' [Mr. Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto ceased , and sat twitching on [his]120-thaddeus sholto luxurious settee . '[1321-sir] It is possible that [we]414-we may be able to make [you]0-i some small return by throwing some light upon that which is still dark to [you]0-i . ' [[Our]414-we new acquaintance]1434-our new acquaintance very deliberately coiled up the tube of [his]0-i hookah , and produced from behind a curtain a very long befrogged topcoat with Astrakhan collar and cuffs . This [he]0-i buttoned tightly up , in spite of the extreme closeness of the night , and finished [his]0-i attire by putting on a rabbitskin cap with hanging lappets which covered the ears , so that no part of [him]0-i was visible save [his]0-i mobile and peaky face . '[0-i] [My]0-i health is somewhat fragile , ' [he]0-i remarked , as [he]0-i led the way down [the passage]1435-the passage . '[0-i] [I]0-i am compelled to be [a valetudinarian]425-a valetudinarian . ' [[Our]414-we cab]1378-our cab was awaiting [us]414-we outside , and [our]414-we programme was evidently prearranged , for [the driver]1370-the driver started off at once at a rapid pace . [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto talked incessantly , in a voice which rose high above the rattle of the wheels . '[0-i] [Bartholomew]130-brother bartholomew is [a clever fellow]426-a clever fellow , ' said [he]120-thaddeus sholto . '[426-a clever fellow] How do [you]427-our think [he]130-brother bartholomew found out where the treasure was ? [He]130-brother bartholomew had come to the conclusion that it was somewhere [indoors]428-indoors : so [he]130-brother bartholomew worked out all the cubic space of [the house]1422-the house , and made measurements everywhere , so that not one inch should be unaccounted for . Among other things , [he]130-brother bartholomew found that the height of [the building]430-the building was seventy - four feet , but on adding together the heights of all [the separate rooms]431-the separate rooms , and making every allowance for the space between , which [he]130-brother bartholomew ascertained by borings , [he]130-brother bartholomew could not bring the total to more than seventy feet . There were four feet unaccounted for . These could only be at the top of [the building]430-the building . [He]130-brother bartholomew knocked a hole , therefore , in the lath and plaster ceiling of [the highest room]433-the highest room , and there , sure enough , [he]130-brother bartholomew came upon another little garret above [it]433-the highest room , which had been sealed up and was known to [no one]229-no one . In the centre stood the treasure - chest , resting upon two rafters . [He]130-brother bartholomew lowered it through the hole , and there it lies . [He]130-brother bartholomew computes the value of the jewels at not less than half a million sterling . ' At the mention of this gigantic sum [we]427-our all stared at [one another]1438-one another open - eyed . [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan , could [we]427-our secure [her]116-miss morstan rights , would change from [a needy governess]1439-a needy governess to [the richest heiress in [England]6-england]1440-the richest heiress in england . [I]130-brother bartholomew stammered out some few halting words of congratulation , and then sat downcast , with [my]130-brother bartholomew head drooped , deaf to the babble of [[our]427-our new acquaintance]1434-our new acquaintance . [He]130-brother bartholomew was clearly a confirmed hypochondriac , and [I]130-brother bartholomew was dreamily conscious that [he]130-brother bartholomew was pouring forth interminable trains of symptoms , and imploring information as to the composition and action of innumerable quack nostrums , some of which [he]130-brother bartholomew bore about in a leather case in [his]130-brother bartholomew pocket . [Holmes]108-holmes declares that [he]108-holmes overheard [me]130-brother bartholomew caution [him]130-brother bartholomew against the great danger of taking more than two drops of castor - oil , while [I]130-brother bartholomew recommended strychnine in large doses as a sedative . '[130-brother bartholomew] This , [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan , is [Pondicherry Lodge]27-pondicherry lodge , ' said [Mr. Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto , as [he]120-thaddeus sholto handed [her]116-miss morstan out . [We]427-our had left the damp fog of [the great city]1352-the great city behind [us]427-our , and the night was fairly fine . A warm wind blew from the westward , and heavy clouds moved slowly across the sky , with half a moon peeping occasionally through the rifts . It was clearenough to see for some distance , but [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto took down one of the sidelamps from [the carriage]1446-the carriage to give [us]427-our a better light upon [our]427-our way . [Pondicherry Lodge]27-pondicherry lodge stood in [[its]27-pondicherry lodge own grounds]1447-its own grounds , and was girt round with a very high stone wall topped with broken glass . '[0-i] Oh , [Mr. Thaddeus]120-thaddeus sholto , [sir]1321-sir , [I]0-i am so glad [you]1321-sir have come ! [Holmes]108-holmes swung it slowly round , and peered keenly at [the house]1422-the house , and at the great rubbish - heaps which cumbered [the grounds]1469-the grounds . [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan and [I]1321-sir stood together , and [her]1466-a tall old woman hand was in [mine]1321-sir . A wondrous subtle thing is love , for here were [we]459-we two , who had never seen [each other before that day , between whom no word or even look of affection had ever passed]1470-each other before that day , between whom no word or even look of affection had ever passed , and yet now in an hour of trouble [our]459-we hands instinctively sought for each other . [I]1321-sir have marvelled at it since , but at the time it seemed the most natural thing that [I]1321-sir should go out to [her]1466-a tall old woman so , and , as [she]1466-a tall old woman has often told [me]1321-sir , there was in [her]1466-a tall old woman also the instinct to turn to [me]1321-sir for comfort and protection . So [we]459-we stood hand - in - hand , like [two children]1471-two children , and there was peace in [our]459-we hearts for all the dark things that surrounded [us]459-we . '[1321-sir] What [a strange place]465-a strange place ! ' [she]1466-a tall old woman said , looking round . '[1321-sir] It looks as though all the moles in [England]6-england had been let loose in [it]465-a strange place . [I]0-i have seen something of the sort on the side of [a hill near [Ballarat]30-ballarat]466-a hill near ballarat , where [the prospectors]467-the prospectors had been at work . ' '[467-the prospectors] And from the same cause , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes . '[467-the prospectors] These are the traces of [the treasure - seekers]468-the treasure - seekers . [You]469-you must remember that [they]468-the treasure - seekers were six years looking for it . No wonder that [the grounds]1469-the grounds look like [a gravel - pit]471-a gravel - pit . ' At that moment the door of [the house]1422-the house burst open , and [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto came running out , with [his]120-thaddeus sholto hands thrown forward and terror in [his]120-thaddeus sholto eyes . '[469-you] There is something amiss with [Bartholomew]130-brother bartholomew ! ' [he]120-thaddeus sholto cried . '[0-i] [I]0-i am frightened ! [My]0-i nerves can not stand it . ' [He]120-thaddeus sholto was , indeed , half blubbering with fear , and [his]120-thaddeus sholto twitching , feeble face peeping out from the great Astrakhan collar had the helpless , appealing expression of [a terrified child]1473-a terrified child . '[0-i] Come into [the house]1422-the house , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes , in [his]108-holmes crisp , firm way . '[0-i] Yes , do ! ' pleaded [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto . '[0-i] [I]0-i really do not feel equal to giving directions . ' [We]1474-we all followed [him]120-thaddeus sholto into [[the housekeeper]457-the housekeeper 's room]458-the housekeeper 's room , which stood upon the left - hand side of [the passage]1435-the passage . [The old woman]1478-the old woman was pacing up and down with a scared look and restless , picking fingers , but the sight of [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan appeared to have a soothing effect upon [her]1478-the old woman . '[0-i] God bless [your]130-brother bartholomew sweet , calm face ! ' [she]1478-the old woman cried , with an hysterical sob . '[130-brother bartholomew] It does [me]0-i good to see [you]130-brother bartholomew . Oh , but [I]0-i have been sorely tried this day ! ' [[Our]1474-we companion]1351-our companion patted [her]1478-the old woman thin , work - worn hand , and murmured some few words of kindly , womanly comfort which brought the colour back into the other 's bloodless cheeks . '[0-i] [Master]473-master has locked [himself]473-master in , and will not answer [me]0-i , ' [she]1478-the old woman explained . '[473-master] All day [I]0-i have waited to hear from [him]473-master , for [he]473-master often likes to be alone ; but an hour ago [I]0-i feared that something was amiss , so [I]0-i went up and peeped through the keyhole . [You]130-brother bartholomew must go up , [Mr. Thaddeus]120-thaddeus sholto — [you]130-brother bartholomew must go up and look for [yourself]130-brother bartholomew . [I]0-i have seen [Mr. Bartholomew Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto in joy and in sorrow for ten long years , but [I]0-i never saw [him]145-bartholomew sholto with such a face on [him]145-bartholomew sholto as that . ' [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes took the lamp and led the way , for [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto 's teeth were chattering in [his]120-thaddeus sholto head . So shaken was [he]120-thaddeus sholto that [I]145-bartholomew sholto had to pass [my]145-bartholomew sholto hand under [his]120-thaddeus sholto arm as [we]1480-we went up [the stairs]1481-the stairs , for [his]120-thaddeus sholto knees were trembling under [him]120-thaddeus sholto . Twice as [we]1480-we ascended [Holmes]108-holmes whipped [his]108-holmes lens out of [his]108-holmes pocket and carefully examined marks which appeared to [me]145-bartholomew sholto to be mere shapeless smudges of dust upon the cocoanut - matting which served as a stair - carpet . [He]108-holmes walked slowly from step to step , holding the lamp low , and shooting keen glances to right and left . [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan had remained behind with [the frightened housekeeper]1482-the frightened housekeeper . [The third flight of stairs]1483-the third flight of stairs ended in a straight passage of some length , with a great picture in Indian tapestry upon the right of [it]1483-the third flight of stairs and three doors upon the left . [Holmes]108-holmes advanced along [it]1483-the third flight of stairs in the same slow and methodical way , while [we]1480-we kept close at [his]108-holmes heels , with [our]1480-we long black shadows streaming backwards down [the corridor]1484-the corridor . The third door was that which [we]1480-we were seeking . [Holmes]108-holmes knocked without receiving any answer , and then tried to turn the handle and force it open . It was locked on the inside , however , and by a broad and powerful bolt , as [we]1480-we could see when [we]1480-we set [our]1480-we lamp up against it . The key being turned , however , the hole was not entirely closed . [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes bent down to it , and instantly rose again with a sharp intaking of the breath . '[145-bartholomew sholto] There is something devilish in this , [Watson]109-watson , ' said [he]108-holmes , more moved than [I]109-watson had ever before seen [him]108-holmes . '[109-watson] What do [you]109-watson make of it ? ' [I]109-watson stooped to the hole , and recoiled in horror . Moonlight was streaming into [the room]233-the room , and it was bright with a vague and shifty radiance . Looking straight at [me]109-watson , and suspended , as it were , in the air , for all beneath was in shadow , there hung a face — the very face of [[our]1480-we companion]1351-our companion [Thaddeus]120-thaddeus sholto . There was the same high , shining head , the same circular bristle of red hair , the same bloodless countenance . The features were set , however , in a horrible smile , a fixed and unnatural grin , which in [that still and moonlit room]1487-that still and moonlit room was more jarring to the nerves than any scowl or contortion . So like was the face to that of [[our]1480-we little friend]1488-our little friend that [I]109-watson looked round at [him]108-holmes to make sure that [he]108-holmes was indeed with [us]1480-we . Then [I]109-watson recalled to mind that [he]108-holmes had mentioned to [us]1480-we that [[his]108-holmes brother]1489-his brother and [he]108-holmes were [twins]1490-twins . '[109-watson] This is terrible ! ' [I]109-watson said to [Holmes]108-holmes . '[109-watson] What is to be done ? ' '[109-watson] The door must come down , ' [he]108-holmes answered , and , springing against it , [he]108-holmes put all [his]108-holmes weight upon the lock . It creaked and groaned , but did not yield . Together [we]1480-we flung [ourselves]1480-we upon it once more , and this time it gave way with a sudden snap , and [we]1480-we found [ourselves]1480-we within [[Bartholomew Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto 's chamber]1491-bartholomew sholto 's chamber . [It]1491-bartholomew sholto 's chamber appeared to have been fitted up as [a chemical laboratory]1492-a chemical laboratory . A double line of glass - stoppered bottles was drawn up upon the wall opposite the door , and the table was littered over with Bunsen burners , test - tubes , and retorts . In the corners stood carboys of acid in wicker baskets . One of these appeared to leak or to have been broken , for a stream of dark - coloured liquid had trickled out from it , and the air was heavy with a peculiarly pungent , tar - like odour . A set of steps stood at one side of [the room]233-the room , in the midst of a litter of lath and plaster , and above [them]1494-them there was an opening in the ceiling large enough for [a man]1293-a man to pass through . At the foot of the steps a long coil of rope was thrown carelessly together . By the table , in a wooden arm - chair , [the master of [the house]1422-the house]1496-the master of the house was seated all in a heap , with [his]1496-the master of the house head sunk upon [his]1496-the master of the house left shoulder , and that ghastly , inscrutable smile upon [his]1496-the master of the house face . [He]1496-the master of the house was stiff and cold , and had clearly been dead many hours . It seemed to [me]474-me that not only [his]1496-the master of the house features , but all [his]1496-the master of the house limbs , were twisted and turned in the most fantastic fashion . By [his]1496-the master of the house hand upon the table there lay a peculiar instrument — a brown , closegrained stick , with a stone head like a hammer , rudely lashed on with coarse twine . Beside it was a torn sheet of note - paper with some words scrawled upon it . [Holmes]108-holmes glanced at it , and then handed it to [me]474-me . '[474-me] [You]474-me see , ' [he]108-holmes said , with a significant raising of the eyebrows . In the light of the lantern [I]474-me read , with a thrill of horror , '[474-me] The sign of the four . ' '[474-me] In [God]143-god 's name , what does it all mean ? ' [I]143-god asked . '[143-god] It means murder , ' said [he]108-holmes , stooping over [the dead man]1498-the dead man . '[143-god] Ah ! [I]0-i expected it . Look here ! ' [He]108-holmes pointed to what looked like a long dark thorn stuck in the skin just above the ear . '[143-god] It looks like a thorn , ' said [I.]143-god '[143-god] It is a thorn . [You]474-me may pick it out . But be careful , for it is poisoned . ' [I]143-god took it up between [my]143-god finger and thumb . It came away from the skin so readily that hardly any mark was left behind . One tiny speck of blood showed where the puncture had been . '[143-god] This is all an insoluble mystery to [me]0-i , ' said [I.]143-god '[143-god] It grows darker instead of clearer . '[108-holmes] [He]108-holmes mounted the steps , and , seizing a rafter with either hand , [he]108-holmes swung [himself]108-holmes up into [the garret]493-the garret . [The chamber in which [we]495-we found [ourselves]495-we]494-the chamber in which we found ourselves was about ten feet one way and six the other . The roof ran up to an apex , and was evidently the inner shell of the true roof of [the house]1422-the house . There was no furniture of any sort , and the accumulated dust of years lay thick upon the floor . So swift , silent , and furtive were [his]0-i movements , like those of a trained bloodhound picking out a scent , that [I]0-i could not but think what [a terrible criminal]1532-a terrible criminal [he]0-i would have made had [he]0-i turned [his]0-i energy and sagacity against the law , instead of exerting them in its defence . As [he]0-i hunted about , [he]0-i kept muttering to [himself]0-i , and finally [he]0-i broke out into a loud crow of delight . '[0-i] [We]503-we are certainly in luck , ' said [he]0-i . '[0-i] [We]503-we ought to have very little trouble now . [Number One]146-number one has had the misfortune to tread in [the creosote]504-the creosote . [The carboy]506-the carboy has been cracked , [you]505-you see , and the stuff has leaked out . ' '[505-you] What then ? ' [I]505-you asked . '[505-you] Why , [we]503-we have got [him]146-number one , that 's all , ' said [he]0-i . '[0-i] [I]0-i know a dog that would follow that scent to [the world]205-the world 's end . If a pack can track a trailed herring across [a shire]508-a shire , how far can a specially - trained hound follow so pungent a smell as this ? It sounds like a sum in the rule of three . The answer should give [us]503-we the — But hallo ! here are [the accredited representatives of the law]509-the accredited representatives of the law . ' Heavy steps and the clamour of loud voices were audible from below , and [the hall]1533-the hall door shut with a loud crash . '[509-the accredited representatives of the law] Before [they]509-the accredited representatives of the law come , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes , '[509-the accredited representatives of the law] just put [your]505-you hand here on [this poor fellow]510-this poor fellow 's arm , and here on [his]510-this poor fellow leg . What do [you]505-you feel ? ' '[505-you] The muscles are as hard as a board , ' [I]505-you answered . '[505-you] Quite so . [They]511-they are in a state of extreme contraction , far exceeding the usual rigor mortis . ' '[505-you] That was the idea which occurred to [me]0-i the instant [I]0-i saw the drawn muscles of the face . On getting into [the room]233-the room [I]0-i at once looked for the means by which the poison had entered the system . As [you]505-you saw , [I]0-i discovered a thorn which had been driven or shot with no great force into the scalp . [You]505-you observe that the part struck was that which would be turned towards the hole in the ceiling if [the man]1403-the man were erect in [his]1403-the man chair . Now examine this thorn . ' [I]515-the regulars took it up gingerly and held it in the light of the lantern . It was long , sharp , and black , with a glazed look near the point as though some gummy substance had dried upon it . The blunt end had been trimmed and rounded off with a knife . '[515-the regulars] Is that an English thorn ? ' [he]0-i asked . '[515-the regulars] No , it certainly is not . ' '[515-the regulars] With all these data [you]505-you should be able to draw some just inference . But here are [the regulars]515-the regulars : so [the auxiliary forces]516-the auxiliary forces may beat a retreat . ' As [he]0-i spoke , the steps which had been coming nearer sounded loudly on [the passage]1435-the passage , and [a very stout , portly man in a gray suit]1535-a very stout , portly man in a gray suit strode heavily into [the room]233-the room . [He]1535-a very stout , portly man in a gray suit was red - faced , burly , and plethoric , with a pair of very small twinkling eyes which looked keenly out from between swollen and puffy pouches . [He]1535-a very stout , portly man in a gray suit was closely followed by [an inspector in uniform]1537-an inspector in uniform , and by the still palpitating [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto . '[515-the regulars] Here 's a business ! ' [he]1535-a very stout , portly man in a gray suit cried , in a muffled , husky voice . '[515-the regulars] Here 's a pretty business ! But who are all these ? Why , [the house]1422-the house seems to be as full as [a rabbit - warren]518-a rabbit - warren ! ' '[0-i] [I]0-i think [you]505-you must recollect [me]0-i , [Mr. Athelney Jones]112-jones , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes quietly . '[505-you] Why , of course [I]0-i do ! Now [I]0-i make one with [my]0-i naked foot beside it . What is the chief difference ? ' '[109-watson] [Your]109-watson toes are all cramped together . The other print has each toe distinctly divided . ' '[109-watson] Quite so . That is the point . Bear that in mind . Now , would [you]109-watson kindly step over to that flap - window and smell the edge of the wood - work ? [I]0-i shall stay over here , as [I]0-i have this handkerchief in [my]0-i hand . ' [I]0-i did as [he]0-i directed , and was instantly conscious of a strong tarry smell . '[0-i] That is where [he]600-he put [his]600-he foot in getting out . If [you]109-watson can trace [him]600-he , [I]0-i should think that [Toby]149-toby will have no difficulty . Now run [downstairs]601-downstairs , loose the dog , and look out for [Blondin]152-blondin . ' By the time that [I]109-watson got out into [the grounds]1469-the grounds [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes was on the roof , and [I]109-watson could see [him]108-holmes like an enormous glow - worm crawling very slowly along the ridge . [I]109-watson lost sight of [him]108-holmes behind a stack of chimneys , but [he]108-holmes presently reappeared , and then vanished once more upon the opposite side . When [I]109-watson made [my]109-watson way round [there]248-there [I]109-watson found [him]108-holmes seated at one of the corner eaves . '[109-watson] That [you]109-watson , [Watson]109-watson ? ' [he]108-holmes cried . '[109-watson] Yes . ' '[109-watson] This is [the place]592-the place . What is that black thing down there ? ' '[109-watson] A water - barrel . ' '[109-watson] Top on it ? ' '[109-watson] Yes . ' '[109-watson] No sign of a ladder ? ' '[109-watson] No . ' '[109-watson] Confound [the fellow]603-the fellow ! It 's [a most breakneck place]604-a most breakneck place . [I]0-i ought to be able to come down where [he]603-the fellow could climb up . The water - pipe feels pretty firm . Here goes , anyhow . ' There was a scuffling of feet , and the lantern began to come steadily down the side of the wall . Then with a light spring [he]108-holmes came on to the barrel , and from there to [the earth]1588-the earth . '[603-the fellow] It was easy to follow [him]603-the fellow , ' [he]108-holmes said , drawing on [his]108-holmes stockings and boots . '[603-the fellow] Tiles were loosened the whole way along , and in [his]603-the fellow hurry [he]603-the fellow had dropped this . It confirms [my]0-i diagnosis , as [you]605-you doctors express it . ' The object which [he]108-holmes held up to [me]603-the fellow was a small pocket or pouch woven out of coloured grasses and with a few tawdry beads strung round it . In shape and size it was not unlike a cigarette - case . Inside were half a dozen spines of dark wood , sharp at one end and rounded at the other , like that which had struck [Bartholomew Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto . '[603-the fellow] They are hellish things , ' said [he]108-holmes . '[603-the fellow] Look out that [you]109-watson do n't prick [yourself]109-watson . [I]0-i 'm delighted to have them , for the chances are that they are all [he]603-the fellow has . '[0-i] ' Here [you]603-the fellow are , [doggy]1591-doggy ! [Good old Toby]149-toby ! Smell it , [Toby]149-toby , smell it ! '[0-i] [he]0-i pushed the creosote handkerchief under the dog 's nose , while the creature stood with its fluffy legs separated , and with a most comical cock to [its]606-his head , like a connoisseur sniffing the bouquet of a famous vintage . [Holmes]108-holmes then threw the handkerchief to a distance , fastened a stout cord to the mongrel 's collar , and led [him]606-his to the foot of the water - barrel . The creature instantly broke into a succession of high , tremulous yelps , and , with [his]606-his nose on the ground , and [his]606-his tail in the air , pattered off upon [the trail]607-the trail at a pace which strained [his]606-his leash and kept [us]608-us at the top of [our]608-us speed . The east had been gradually whitening , and [we]608-us could now see some distance in the cold gray light . [The square , massive house]609-the square , massive house , with [its]609-the square , massive house black , empty windows and high , bare walls , towered up , sad and forlorn , behind [us]608-us . [Our]608-us course led right across [the grounds]1469-the grounds , in and out among the trenches and pits with which [they]1469-the grounds were scarred and intersected . [The whole place]611-the whole place , with [its]609-the square , massive house scattered dirt - heaps and ill - grown shrubs , had a blighted , ill - omened look which harmonized with the black tragedy which hung over it . On reaching the boundary wall [Toby]149-toby ran along , whining eagerly , underneath its shadow , and stopped finally in a corner screened by a young beech . Where the two walls joined , several bricks had been loosened , and the crevices left were worn down and rounded upon the lower side , as though they had frequently been used as a ladder . [Holmes]108-holmes clambered up , and , taking the dog from [me]0-i , [he]108-holmes dropped it over upon the other side . ' There 's the print of wooden - leg 's hand , '[108-holmes] [he]108-holmes remarked , as [I]0-i mounted up beside [him]108-holmes . ' [You]0-i see the slight smudge of blood upon the white plaster . What a lucky thing it is that [we]608-us have had no very heavy rain since yesterday ! The scent will lie upon [the road]1592-the road in spite of [their]1592-the road eight - and - twenty hours '[108-holmes] start . ' [I]108-holmes confess that [I]108-holmes had [my]108-holmes doubts [myself]108-holmes when [I]108-holmes reflected upon the great traffic which had passed along [the London road]1593-the london road in the interval . [My]108-holmes fears were soon appeased , however . [Toby]149-toby never hesitated or swerved , but waddled on in [his]149-toby peculiar rolling fashion . Clearly , the pungent smell of the creasote rose high above all other contending scents . '[108-holmes] Do not imagine , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes , '[108-holmes] that [I]0-i depend for [my]0-i success in this case upon the mere chance of [one of [these fellows]613-these fellows]612-one of these fellows having put [his]612-one of these fellows foot in the chemical . [I]0-i have knowledge now which would enable [me]0-i to trace [them]613-these fellows in many different ways . This , however , is the readiest , and , since fortune has put it into [our]614-our hands , [I]0-i should be culpable if [I]0-i neglected it . It has , however , prevented the case from becoming the pretty little intellectual problem which it at one time promised to be . There might have been some credit to be gained out of it , but for this too palpable clue . ' '[0-i] There is credit , and to spare , ' said [I.]0-i '[0-i] [I]0-i assure [you]615-you , [Holmes]108-holmes , that [I]0-i marvel at the means by which [you]615-you obtain [your]615-you results in this case , even more than [I]0-i did in the Jefferson Hope murder . ' '[615-you] [Pshaw]153-pshaw , [[my]0-i dear boy]617-my dear boy ! it was simplicity itself . [I]0-i do n't wish to be theatrical . It is all patent and above - board . [Two officers who are in command of [a convict - guard]619-a convict - guard]618-two officers who are in command of a convict - guard learn an important secret as to buried treasure . [You]621-you remember that [we]622-we saw the name upon the chart in [Captain Morstan]119-captain morstan 's possession . [He]119-captain morstan had signed it in behalf of [himself]119-captain morstan and [[his]119-captain morstan associates]623-his associates — the sign of the four , as [he]119-captain morstan somewhat dramatically called it . Aided by this chart , [the officers]624-the officers — or [one of [them]624-the officers]381-one of them — gets the treasure and brings it to [England]6-england , leaving , [we]622-we will suppose , some condition under which [he]119-captain morstan received it unfulfilled . The chart is dated at a time when [Morstan]119-captain morstan was brought into close association with [convicts]626-convicts . [Jonathan Small]124-small did not get the treasure because [he]124-small and [[his]124-small associates]623-his associates were [themselves]628-themselves [convicts]626-convicts and could not get away . ' '[124-small] But this is mere speculation , ' said [I.]1594-i. '[124-small] It is more than that . It is the only hypothesis which covers the facts . Let [us]622-we see how it fits in with the sequel . [Major Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto remains at peace for some years , happy in the possession of [his]145-bartholomew sholto treasure . Does the reasoning strike [you]633-you as being faulty ? ' '[124-small] No : it is clear and concise . ' '[124-small] Well , now , let [us]638-we put [ourselves]638-we in the place of [Jonathan Small]124-small . Let [us]638-we look at it from [his]124-small point of view . ' '[656-you] Very clearly . ' '[656-you] Now , what could [Jonathan Small]124-small do ? [He]124-small could only continue to keep a secret watch upon the efforts made to find the treasure . Strange dogs sauntered up and stared wonderingly at [us]666-we as [we]666-we passed , but [our]666-we inimitable [Toby]149-toby looked neither to the right or to the left , but trotted onwards with [his]149-toby nose to the ground and an occasional eager whine which spoke of a hot scent . [We]666-we had traversed [Streatham]35-streatham , [Brixton]36-brixton , [Camberwell]37-camberwell , and now found [ourselves]666-we in [Kennington Lane]38-kennington lane , having borne away through [the side streets to the east of [the Oval]39-the oval]1603-the side streets to the east of the oval . Where [the latter street]1609-the latter street turns into [[Knight]162-knight 's Place]1610-knight 's place , [Toby]149-toby ceased to advance , but began to run backwards and forwards with one ear cocked and the other drooping , the very picture of canine indecision . Then [he]149-toby waddled round in circles , looking up to [us]666-we from time to time , as if to ask for sympathy in [his]149-toby embarrassment . '[0-i] What the deuce is the matter with the dog ? ' growled [Holmes]108-holmes . '[677-they] [They]677-they surely would not take [a cab]547-a cab , or go off in a balloon . ' '[677-they] Perhaps [they]677-they stood [here]354-here for some time , ' [I]677-they suggested . '[677-they] Ah ! it 's all right . [He]680-he 's off again , ' said [[my]680-he companion]202-my companion , in a tone of relief . [He]680-he was indeed off , for after sniffing round again [he]680-he suddenly made up [his]680-he mind , and darted away with an energy and determination such as [he]680-he had not yet shown . The scent appeared to be much hotter than before , for [he]680-he had not even to put [his]680-he nose on the ground , but tugged at [his]680-he leash and tried to break into a run . [I]680-he could see by the gleam in [Holmes]108-holmes 's eyes that [he]108-holmes thought [we]1612-we were nearing the end of [our]1612-we journey . [Our]1612-we course now ran down [Nine Elms]42-nine elms until [we]1612-we came to [Broderick]43-broderick and [[Nelson]163-nelson 's large timber - yard]1613-nelson 's large timber - yard , just past [the White Eagle tavern]1614-the white eagle tavern . Here the dog , frantic with excitement , turned down through the side gate into [the enclosure]1615-the enclosure , where [the sawyers]1616-the sawyers were already at work . On the dog raced through sawdust and shavings , down [an alley]1617-an alley , round [a passage]1618-a passage , between two wood - piles , and finally , with a triumphant yelp , sprang upon a large barrel which still stood upon the hand - trolley on which it had been brought . With lolling tongue and blinking eyes , [Toby]149-toby stood upon the cask , looking from one to the other of [us]1612-we for some sign of appreciation . The staves of the barrel and the wheels of the trolley were smeared with a dark liquid , and the whole air was heavy with the smell of creosote . [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes and [I]680-he looked blankly at [each other]1408-each other , and then burst simultaneously into an uncontrollable fit of laughter . '[680-he] What now ? ' [I]149-toby asked . '[149-toby] [Toby]149-toby has lost [his]149-toby character for infallibility . ' '[149-toby] [He]149-toby acted according to [his]149-toby lights , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes , lifting [him]149-toby down from the barrel and walking [him]149-toby out of [the timber - yard]1620-the timber - yard . '[149-toby] If [you]681-you consider how much creosote is carted about [London]8-london in one day , it is no great wonder that [our]682-we trail should have been crossed . It is much used now , especially for the seasoning of wood . [Poor Toby]149-toby is not to blame . ' '[149-toby] [We]682-we must get on the main scent again , [I]0-i suppose . ' '[0-i] Yes . And , fortunately , [we]682-we have no distance to go . Evidently what puzzled the dog at [the corner of [Knight 's Place]44-knight 's place]683-the corner of knight 's place was that there were two different trails running in opposite directions . [We]682-we took the wrong one . It only remains to follow the other . ' There was no difficulty about this . On leading [Toby]149-toby to the place where [he]149-toby had committed [his]149-toby fault , [he]149-toby cast about in a wide circle and finally dashed off in a fresh direction . '[682-we] [We]682-we must take care that [he]149-toby does not now bring [us]682-we to the place where [the creosote - barrel]684-the creosote - barrel came from , ' [I]0-i observed . '[0-i] [I]0-i had thought of that . But [you]681-you notice that [he]149-toby keeps on [the pavement]1290-the pavement , whereas the barrel passed down [the roadway]686-the roadway . No , [we]682-we are on the true scent now . ' It tended down towards [the river - side]1621-the river - side , running through [Belmont Place]45-belmont place and [Prince 's Street]46-prince 's street . At the end of [Broad Street]47-broad street [it]1622-it ran right down to [the water]1623-the water 's edge , where there was [a small wooden wharf]1624-a small wooden wharf . [Toby]149-toby led [us]682-we to the very edge of this , and there stood whining , looking out on the dark current beyond . '[682-we] [We]682-we are out of luck , ' said [Holmes]108-holmes . '[682-we] [They]687-they have taken to [a boat]688-a boat here . ' Several small punts and skiffs were lying about in the water and on the edge of [the wharf]1625-the wharf . [We]682-we took [Toby]149-toby round to each in turn , but , though [he]149-toby sniffed earnestly , [he]149-toby made no sign . Close to [the rude landing - stage]1626-the rude landing - stage was [a small brick house]1627-a small brick house , with a wooden placard slung out through the second window . '[687-they] [Mordecai Smith]164-mordecai smith ' was printed across it in large letters , and , underneath , '[687-they] Boats to hire by the hour or day . ' A second inscription above the door informed [us]682-we that a steam launch was kept — a statement which was confirmed by a great pile of coke upon [the jetty]1628-the jetty . [Sherlock Holmes]108-holmes looked slowly round , and [his]108-holmes face assumed an ominous expression . '[687-they] This looks bad , ' said [he]108-holmes . '[687-they] [These fellows]613-these fellows are sharper than [I]0-i expected . [They]613-these fellows seem to have covered [their]613-these fellows tracks . ' [He]108-holmes was approaching the door of [the house]1422-the house , when it opened , and [a little curly - headed lad of six]1630-a little curly - headed lad of six came running out , followed by [a stoutish , red - faced woman]1631-a stoutish , red - faced woman with a large sponge in [her]1631-a stoutish , red - faced woman hand . '[0-i] [You]690-you come back and be washed , [Jack]165-jack , ' [she]1631-a stoutish , red - faced woman shouted . '[165-jack] Come back , [[you]165-jack young imp]691-you young imp ; for if [[your]165-jack father]1297-your father comes [home]1329-home and finds [you]165-jack like that , [he]1297-your father 'll let [us]694-us hear of it . ' It was between eight and nine o'clock now , and [I]169-wiggins was conscious of a strong reaction after the successive excitements of the night . [I]169-wiggins was limp and weary , befogged in mind and fatigued in body . [I]169-wiggins had not the professional enthusiasm which carried [[my]169-wiggins companion]202-my companion on , nor could [I]169-wiggins look at the matter as a mere abstract intellectual problem . As far as the death of [Bartholomew Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto went , [I]169-wiggins had heard little good of [him]145-bartholomew sholto , and could feel no intense antipathy to [[his]145-bartholomew sholto murderers]1653-his murderers . The treasure , however , was a different matter . That , or part of it , belonged rightfully to [Miss Morstan]116-miss morstan . While there was a chance of recovering it [I]169-wiggins was ready to devote [my]169-wiggins life to the one object . Yet it would be a petty and selfish love which would be influenced by such a thought as that . If [Holmes]108-holmes could work to find [the criminals]1654-the criminals , [I]169-wiggins had a tenfold stronger reason to urge [me]169-wiggins on to find the treasure . When [I]169-wiggins came down to [[our]1655-our room]1656-our room [I]169-wiggins found the breakfast laid and [Holmes]108-holmes pouring out the coffee . ' '[169-wiggins] About twelve o'clock last night , ' said [the Standard]1657-the standard , '[169-wiggins] [Mr. Bartholomew Sholto]145-bartholomew sholto , of [Pondicherry Lodge]27-pondicherry lodge , Upper [Norwood]26-norwood , was found dead in [[his]145-bartholomew sholto room]390-his room under circumstances which point to foul play . [His]112-jones trained and experienced faculties were at once directed towards the detection of [the criminals]1654-the criminals , with the gratifying result that [the brother]528-the brother , [Thaddeus Sholto]120-thaddeus sholto , has already been arrested , together with [the housekeeper]457-the housekeeper , [Mrs. Bernstone]144-mrs. bernstone , [an Indian butler named [Lal Rao]156-lal rao]767-an indian butler named lal rao , and [a porter]768-a porter , or gatekeeper , named [McMurdo]141-mcmurdo . It is quite certain that [the thief]769-the thief or [thieves]770-thieves were well acquainted with [the house]1422-the house , for [Mr. Jones]112-jones 's well - known technical knowledge and [his]112-jones powers of minute observation have enabled [him]112-jones to prove conclusively that [the miscreants]772-the miscreants could not have entered by the door or by the window , but must have made [their]772-the miscreants way across the roof of [the building]430-the building , and so through a trap - door into [a room which communicated with that in which the body was found]774-a room which communicated with that in which the body was found . This fact , which has been very clearly made out , proves conclusively that it was no mere haphazard burglary . The prompt and energetic action of [the officers of the law]775-the officers of the law shows the great advantage of the presence on such occasions of a single vigorous and masterful mind . " [The aborigines of [the Andaman Islands]9-the andaman islands]1693-the aborigines of the andaman islands may perhaps claim the distinction of being the smallest race upon [this earth]1694-this earth , though [some anthropologists]1695-some anthropologists prefer [the Bushmen of [Africa]62-africa]1696-the bushmen of africa , [the Digger Indians of [America]63-america]1697-the digger indians of america , and [the Terra del Fuegians]1698-the terra del fuegians . The average height is rather below four feet , although [many full - grown adults]1699-many full - grown adults may be found who are very much smaller than this . [They]1699-many full - grown adults are [a fierce , morose , and intractable people]1700-a fierce , morose , and intractable people , though capable of forming most devoted friendships when [their]1699-many full - grown adults confidence has once been gained . " Mark that , [Watson]109-watson . Now , then , listen to this . " [They]1699-many full - grown adults are naturally hideous , having large , misshapen heads , small fierce eyes , and distorted features . [Their]1699-many full - grown adults feet and hands , however , are remarkably small . So intractable and fierce are [they]1699-many full - grown adults , that all the efforts of [the British officials]1701-the british officials have failed to win [them]1699-many full - grown adults over in any degree . [They]1699-many full - grown adults have always been a terror to [shipwrecked crews]1702-shipwrecked crews , braining [the survivors]1703-the survivors with [their]1703-the survivors stone - headed clubs , or shooting [them]1703-the survivors with [their]1703-the survivors poisoned arrows . These massacres are invariably concluded by a cannibal feast . " [Nice , amiable people]1704-nice , amiable people , [Watson]109-watson ! If [this fellow]297-this fellow had been left to [his]297-this fellow own unaided devices , this affair might have taken an even more ghastly turn . [I]788-i fancy that , even as it is , [Jonathan Small]124-small would give a good deal not to have employed [him]297-this fellow . '[788-i] ' But how came [he]297-this fellow to have so singular [a companion]1706-a companion ? '[789-his] ' Ah , that is more than [I]789-his can tell . Since , however , [we]1707-we had already determined that [Small]124-small had come from [the Andamans]158-the andamans , it is not so very wonderful that [this islander]1708-this islander should be with [him]297-this fellow . Lie down there on the sofa , and see if [I]789-his can put [you]109-watson to sleep . '[789-his] [He]789-his took up [his]789-his violin from the corner , and as [I]0-i stretched [myself]0-i out [he]789-his began to play some low , dreamy , melodious air — [his]789-his own , no doubt , for [he]789-his had a remarkable gift for improvisation . [I]0-i had never known [him]202-my companion to be wrong , and yet [the keenest reasoner]815-the keenest reasoner may occasionally be deceived . '[112-jones] A heavy step was heard ascending the stair , with a great wheezing and rattling as from [a man who was sorely put to it for breath]822-a man who was sorely put to it for breath .
